title: Why do we have to say 'pay tribute' instead of 'give tribute'? - Quora

response.answer_text: Why do we have to say "pay tribute" instead of "give tribute"? Tribute (Latin tributum) was paid in ancient Rome, in goods or money, to dignitaries in return for services, or exchanged as a form of goodwill between cities. Thence, we pay tribute. That’s not the full story though, because we also pay attention, pay a visit and pay our regards, and I’m not sure that we can blame the Romans for all those usages. As with so many English expressions, the reasons may be lost in history and they may not always seem logical, but they have stuck.

In modern talk, ‘pay tribute’ means that tribute is owed to someone for some objectively good thing they have done and are popularly recognized for. ‘Give thanks’ or ‘thank’ means you personally are, well, thanking them for something that you subjectively consider good that they have done for you personally (or your group) regardless of what the general public thinks.
